componenttext: Welcome to Teradata's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's conference. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Gregg Swearingen, Vice President, Investor Relations. Mr. Swearingen, you may begin.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for our 2010 third quarter earnings call. Mike Koehler, Teradata's CEO, will begin our discussion summarizing Teradata's third quarter results. Steve Scheppmann, Teradata's Chief Financial Officer, will then provide
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for our 2010 third quarter earnings call. Mike Koehler, Teradata's CEO, will begin our discussion summarizing Teradata's third quarter results. Steve Scheppmann, Teradata's Chief Financial Officer, will then provide more details relating to our financial performance as well as our increased 2010 guidance. Darryl McDonald, Teradata's Executive Vice President of Business Development and Marketing is also in the room to answer questions.
Our discussion today includes forecast and other information that are considered forward-looking statements. While these statements reflect our current outlook, they are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to vary materially. These risk factors are described in Teradata's 10-K and other filings with the SEC. On today's call, we will also be discussing certain non-GAAP financial information such as earnings per share, excluding stock-based compensation expense, free cash flow and revenue comparisons in constant currency. A reconciliation of our non-GAAP results to our reported GAAP results and other information concerning these measures of is included in our earnings release and on the Investor page of Teradata's website, teradata.com. A replay of this conference call will also be available later today on our website. Teradata assumes no obligation to update or revise the information included in this conference call whether as a result of new information or future results. I'll now turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gregg. And good morning, everyone. Teradata has delivered another strong quarter in Q3, with revenue growth of 15% and operating income growth of 20% versus prior year. Product revenue was up 27% in the quarter and for the year is up 25%. This is
componenttext:
Thanks, Gregg. And good morning, everyone. Teradata has delivered another strong quarter in Q3, with revenue growth of 15% and operating income growth of 20% versus prior year. Product revenue was up 27% in the quarter and for the year is up 25%. This is the highest total revenue growth and product revenue growth we have achieved during the past 10 years.
Data volumes continue to grow exponentially, with new data types coming from new data sources. As companies look to bring these new data elements together with traditional data, this makes for an attractive market opportunity for Teradata and our integrated active data warehouses. This has also created demand for our appliances to address big data and other evolving opportunities in large, single subject data marts. We continue to innovate on many fronts to capitalize on the evolving landscape from big data to advanced analytics, to enterprise marketing management, to mobile intelligence. These innovations are translating into growth in our customer base and growth in the number of customers that Teradata serves. New customer wins year-to-date are at our highest levels in 6 years.
Turning to the regions, the Americas had strong growth again in Q3, with revenue of $292 million, which was up 18% over 2009. New account wins included a world leading manufacturer of aircraft engines, which will integrate and analyze large volumes of text analytics. This will enable them to quickly detect and react to changes that impact its forecasting and manufacturing schedules, which will in turn reduce inventory and service cost. 
Other new account wins included a major high-tech manufacturer and Procter & Gamble and a leading department store retailer as well as the top 2 banks in Mexico and one in Chile. Customer upgrades and expansions included WellPoint, which has added our solid-state drive appliance to deliver critical care alerts to hospital staff and physicians within seconds.
Our Extreme Performance data warehouse, the 4600 Appliance is enabling new time-sensitive, mission-critical, breakthrough applications that were not possible before. Additional upgrades and expansions in the quarter included Nationwide Insurance, Caterpillar Logistics and Enterprise Holdings, which includes Alamo, National and Enterprise Rent-A-Cars and one of the world's largest retailers and one of the world's largest manufacturers of phones and computers. Overall, the Americas is having an outstanding 2010 to date in terms of total revenue growth, product revenue growth and new customer wins. 
In EMEA, Q3 revenue of $109 million was equal to prior year, but it was up 7% in constant currency. New account wins included Unilever, a leading consumer packaged goods company. We are working with CPG manufacturers around the world to integrate, explore and analyze their consumer and retail point-of-sale information to better understand preferences and build brand loyalty. 
EMEA also had 4 government new account wins with 2 in Turkey and one each in Italy and Belarus.
The government sector, as you all know, is an under-penetrated vertical for Teradata and is a big opportunity for us. Upgrades and expansions in the quarter included Lufthansa, which is adding operational over active decision-making and is also redesigning their customer loyalty program and integrating it with partner airlines. And we had expansions at Lloyds, DHL, Telenor Pakistan, the Italian Tax Authority, COOP Norden, Mobinil in Egypt and at Chronopost International in France.
For the first 3 quarters of 2010, EMEA's revenue was flat with 2009 as reported and up 2% in constant currency. However, keep in mind, EMEA was going against the good prior year comparable when revenue grew 9% in constant currency through Q3 2009. EMEA's overall activity has been solid in 2010, and we expect good growth in Q4.
Asia Pacific Japan had an excellent quarter, generating $88 million of revenue in Q3, which was a 28% increase over the third quarter of 2009. In constant currency, APJ grew 19%. China is having a strong 2010, and we continue to see good growth in financial services there, our largest industry.
In Q3, we added Ping An Bank as a new customer, and they will be consolidating 26 data marts into 1 centralized EDW. Ping An Bank joins a growing number of financial services institutions relying on Teradata to provide a single view of the customer, reduce credit risk and drive top and bottom line results. 
During the third quarter, we also recognized significant expansions at several of China's top 5 banks, including ICBC, China Construction Bank and the Bank of Communications.
Across APJ, active EDW implementations are fulfilling mission-critical needs as well. A good example is the Australian border control, which is processing data from a wide range of sources, including near realtime data. The agency will utilize Teradata's event-triggering techniques to rapidly identify, analyze and respond to situations to ensure the safety of Australia's borders.
APJ also saw good growth from a number of other customers across the region in Q3, including the Australian tax authority; in Japan, Rakuten, Japan's largest online retailer; JCB; Mitsui Foods; and Sony Marketing. And in the Philippines, Globe Telecom.
Overall, APJ has grown revenue 15% this year as reported and 7% in constant currency. Growth has been especially strong in the countries outside of Japan. Our Annual Partners Conference was held in San Diego last week with over 3,000 attendees and 169 customers presenting at various sessions there.
One of the common themes from customers in Teradata was how to innovate with the wave of new big data. In particular, how to leverage the big data being driven from weblogs, smartphones, social media, sensors, et cetera, together with what they already know such as customers, products and supply chains.
Organizations that move quickly and figure out how to leverage this new information will have a clear competitive advantage in the marketplace, and Teradata is helping them to do that. I'd like to highlight a few of our announcements from the conference.
We introduced Teradata database 13.10, which further extends our lead with temporal and compression capabilities among other things. Teradata's temporal software automatically timestamps data to allow customers to track and properly account through changes that evolve in their business over time. For example, manufacturers can obtain more meaningful sales performance reports that account for territory realignments or customer mergers and acquisitions that have occurred over the years. And retailers can get sales comparisons that reflect products changing the different categories.
The Teradata database 13.10 has enhanced compression technologies that enable customers to store more data. Customers are receiving up to 20x compression for select data types and up to 4x for overall compression.
We also released the next generation of our platform family of partners, which significantly boost performance across all models and reduces energy consumption as well. For example, our 5650 Active Enterprise Data Warehouse delivers a 43% performance boost over the previous generation and does this in the same-sized footprint, which reduces energy and floor space requirements.
In addition, we announced enhancements to our Customer Relationship Management application which we call CRM. New features include mobile intelligence capabilities, customized reporting and visualization tools. Now marketers and executives can visualize their data and access reports and dashboards across all medium channels from a variety of platforms, including mobile devices and iPads.
In summary, we see more opportunities than ever before to help customers drive value through data warehousing. And we remain confident in our ability to execute with customers and in the market with our best-in-class technology, solutions and the world's best data warehousing consulting practice.
Given our performance in Q3, we are increasing our guidance for 2010 revenue growth to be approximately 12%, and we're increasing our non-GAAP EPS guidance to the $1.80 to $1.83 range.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steve for more details. Steve?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. This quarter, we improved our revenue growth rates, expanded our gross and operating margins and increased our EPS.Now moving to our revenue details. Revenue of $489 million was up 15% from the thir
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. This quarter, we improved our revenue growth rates, expanded our gross and operating margins and increased our EPS.
Now moving to our revenue details. Revenue of $489 million was up 15% from the third quarter of 2009 and also up 15% in constant currency. Revenue for the first 9 months of the year was up 14%, 13% in constant currency. Product revenue of $243 million was up 27% from the third quarter of 2009 and up 25% for the first 9 months.
Services revenue of $246 million was up 5% and 6% year-to-date. Within services, during Q3, consulting services revenue was up 6% and maintenance services revenue was up 5%.
Turning to our gross margin. Gross margin in the third quarter improved to 57.1% compared to 53.4% in the third quarter of 2009. Higher product gross margin and a more favorable mix of product revenue versus services revenue more than offset a lower services gross margin in the quarter. Prior gross margin of 70.4% increased from 62.3% in Q3, 2009. The increase was primarily driven by a positive deal mix, particularly in the Americas region.
Services gross margin in Q3 of 43.9% was lower than the strong services gross margin of 46.2% achieved in Q3 2009. Our consulting services business is expanding their headcount in response to growing business opportunities. As we've discussed in prior quarters, this new headcount can have a negative impact on margin, particularly while the new consultants are being trained and are not yet fully productive or chargeable.
Our data warehousing consulting capability is unmatched and a very important part of our business model. Not only does it enable us to grow services revenue, but it may open the door to future product revenue opportunities.
Moving to a geographical view of gross margin. In the Americas region, gross margin was 61.6%, an improvement from 55.9% in the third quarter of 2009, driven primarily by higher product margins as well as a higher proportion of product revenue as compared to services revenue.
Gross margin in the EMEA region of 51.4% was down from the 53.2% reported in the third quarter of 2009, driven by lower services margins, which were offset somewhat by the improved product margins. 
Gross margin in the APJ region was 48.9%, up from the 44.9% in Q3 2009. The increase was primarily driven by higher product margin as well as a greater proportion of product revenue as compared to the services revenue.
Turning to our expense structure. SG&A expense in Q3 2010 increased $20 million from a year ago. The increase was largely driven by increased selling expenses associated with our strategic initiatives of expanding our sales territories as well as higher variable incentive compensation across the company.
As we discussed last quarter, we expected this level of increase in SG&A expenses and the third quarter of 2009 was abnormally low due to timing, and we curtailed the expenses due to the economy downturn and the associated uncertainty.
R&D in the quarter was $40 million versus $26 million in the third quarter of 2009. As anticipated, we continue to invest in our market-leading technology. For the full year 2010, we expect R&D to be approximately $150 million. FAS 86 unfavorably impacted R&D expense $5 million in Q3 as compared to Q3 2009 and will have an anticipated nonfavorable impact of approximately $11 million for 2010 as compared to 2009.
As a result of all these items discussed, Teradata's operating margin in the third quarter increased to 21.7% versus 20.7% reported in Q3 2009. Increased investments in sales territories and R&D will create more of a headwind on operating margin and EPS in Q4.
That said, however, for the full year 2010, we now expect operating margin to be approximately 21%, higher than the 19% to 20% original guidance range we provided earlier this year below the operating income line. The effective income tax rate in the third quarter of 2010 was 29%, which compared to a 25% effective tax rate in the prior period, driven by an overall proportional increase in U.S. pre-tax earnings. For the full year, Teradata expects a higher proportion of its pre-tax income will be generated in the United States in 2010 as compared to 2009. As a result, we are anticipating the full year effective tax rate to be approximately 27%. However, if the U.S. federal R&D tax credit is not retroactively reinstated by Congress before year end, our full year effective tax rate for 2010 will increase to approximately 28%.
GAAP EPS in Q3 2010 was $0.44 versus $0.36 in Q3 2009. Noncash stock-based compensation expense is included in our EPS results. During the quarter, stock-based compensation expense was approximately $7 million or approximately $0.02 per share.
Non-GAAP EPS for the third quarter, excluding the stock-based compensation expense, was $0.46 in the third quarter of 2010. This compares to $0.40 in the third quarter of 2009, excluding stock-based compensation expense as well as an impairment charge that we took in the third quarter of 2009.
For the full year, we expect approximately the same amount of stock-based compensation expense in 2010 as we had in 2009, roughly $24 million, or approximately $0.09 per share for the full year. As a reminder, we have a table on the footnotes of our earnings release, as well as detailed schedules on our website that reconciles the differences between our GAAP and non-GAAP results and outlook.
Focusing on cash flow, cash from operating activities was $65 million in Q3 2010, versus a $96 million generated in the third quarter of 2009. When comparing to the prior year period, the decrease in cash provided by operating activities was principally driven by the anticipated increase in our receivables balance as well as the higher inventory levels, which are used as a working capital. After $18 million of capital expenditures versus $21 million of CapEx in the third quarter of 2009, we generated $47 million of free cash flow, down from the $75 million free cash flow in Q3 of 2009.
In Q3 2010, the timing of the meaningful revenue growth added to our receivables balance and increased our working capital needs as one would expect. In 2008 and 2009, free cash flow benefited from working down our receivables balance and improving our DSO. Our free cash flow is now expected to run in line with the plus or minus $25 million of net income annual guidance metric we talked about since the spin-off.
Teradata defines free cash flow as cash flow from operating activities less capital expenditures for property and equipment and additions to capitalized software.
With respect to our balance sheet. As of September 30, 2010, we have $741 million of cash, a $17 million increase from the end of the second quarter of 2010. During the third quarter, we used $29 million for tuck-in technology investments and used approximately $17 million to repurchase 559,000 shares of our stock.
As we've said before, we expect that the rate of our buyback will continue to fluctuate each quarter, taking into account, among other things, our working capital needs, our stock price, potential alternative uses of cash such as acquisitions and economic and market conditions.
At the end of Q3 2010, approximately 67% of our cash was held outside the United States and in effect not available for share repurchases unless we repatriate the cash back to the U.S. and pay the corresponding taxes at a significant tax cost.
With respect to our receivables. Our day sales outstanding was 80 days as of September 30, 2010, compared to 70 days as of September 30, 2009. Again, we target approximately 75 to 85 as our DSO targets. To provide further transparency around our currency movement, we provided on our website additional detail regarding how currencies moved in Q3, 2010, and how this movement is expected to impact our year over year revenue comparisons for the remainder of 2010, assuming the currency exchange rates as of the end of October.
As I mentioned earlier, our Q3 total company year over year revenue comparison was not impacted by currency translation, but EMEA region did see 7 points of currency headwind in the year-over-year revenue comparison in the quarter, while APJ benefited from 9 percentage points of currency tailwind. Currencies moved in the favorable directions since our last earnings call. As a result, we now expect 0% to 1% of currency benefit both in the fourth quarter and for the full year revenue comparison.
As Mike said earlier in the call, we are increasing our full year 2010 and EPS guidance ranges. We increased our expectation for revenue growth from the higher end of the 8% to 10% guidance range to approximately 12% and GAAP EPS from the $1.60 to $1.70 to the $1.71 to $1.74 range. Excluding stock-based compensation expense, non-GAAP EPS is now expected to be in the $1.80 to $1.83 range.
As we discussed in the past and as we saw in Q3, some of our cost and expense lines continue to grow faster than normal due to increased investments in sales coverage and R&D along with a more normalized spending in 2010. As a result, we expect our EPS growth to be less than our long-term target of growing EPS of twice our revenue growth, probably more in the 1.5x range. Specifically, as we discussed last quarter and saw in Q3, we anticipate headwind in Q4 from the following factors.
R&D for the full year increasing to approximately $150 million, $11 million due to FAS 86 compared to the 2009 level of $117 million; annualized higher selling expense due to more sales territories and increased training costs associated with new territories and headcount; normal increases in G&A, such as base compensation increases and a return of expenses that were eliminated or reduced in 2009, including training and education; lower services gross margin, as we add to our consulting teams; and finally, potentially higher incentive compensation across the company as the company is performing better relative to key incentive plan metrics as compared to 2009.
That said, we are very pleased with our year-to-date performance, and we feel very good about our technology and competitive leadership positions, which is clearly reflected in our operating results. And consequently, we have increased our guidance for both revenue growth and EPS for 2010.
And with that, operator, we're ready to take questions.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Wamsi Mohan from Bank of America. Please go ahead.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Wamsi Mohan from Bank of America. Please go ahead.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, your implied revenue guidance for 4Q of $526 million compares well to consensus at $521 million, but given the upside this quarter, the seasonality of guidance is somewhat below your normal double digit. Did you see any deals in 3Q. that you're exp
componenttext: Steve, your implied revenue guidance for 4Q of $526 million compares well to consensus at $521 million, but given the upside this quarter, the seasonality of guidance is somewhat below your normal double digit. Did you see any deals in 3Q. that you're expecting to close in 4Q which is causing this dynamic? Or is this continued caution in view of an uncertain demand environment?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Wamsi, I mean Teradata is, we say, lumpy quarter-by-quarter, and the timing of the transactions, we saw some growth from Q4 to Q3 that we're are anticipating, but still within the full year of 2010. So you had some of those dynamics occurring between Q
componenttext: So Wamsi, I mean Teradata is, we say, lumpy quarter-by-quarter, and the timing of the transactions, we saw some growth from Q4 to Q3 that we're are anticipating, but still within the full year of 2010. So you had some of those dynamics occurring between Q3 and Q4 that you'll see in any given year that will affect that quote seasonality.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: Can you quantify, Steve, how much revenue. . .

componenttext: There was nothing unusual, nothing surprised us. But again, when we look at those on a timing wise over a 6-month period, there was nothing that's really out of the unusual, but some of that in fact did occur.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: Okay. And Mike, it looks like you guys spent some capital on acquisitions. I was wondering if you could share some color on these, and if these are geared towards sort of the overall EDW platform, just sort of technology tuck-ins or more specifically geared toward appliances?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The acquisitions were technology tuck-ins that basically enhance our IP across the data warehouse platforms.
componenttext: The acquisitions were technology tuck-ins that basically enhance our IP across the data warehouse platforms.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just my last question is, can you remind us what percent of revenue came from appliances in the quarter, and if you were able to convert any current only appliance customers into EDW customers?
componenttext: And just my last question is, can you remind us what percent of revenue came from appliances in the quarter, and if you were able to convert any current only appliance customers into EDW customers?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the quarter, we were at the lower end of the 5% to 10% product revenue for appliances, and on a year-to-date basis, we're somewhere in the middle of it. In terms of appliances that have upgraded to EDWs in new account opportunities, we do have some ac
componenttext: For the quarter, we were at the lower end of the 5% to 10% product revenue for appliances, and on a year-to-date basis, we're somewhere in the middle of it. In terms of appliances that have upgraded to EDWs in new account opportunities, we do have some activity, but none to date.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bhavan Suri from William Blair & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bhavan Suri from William Blair & Company.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just if you could provide a quick update on the sales teams, the new territories that have been added and how they are executing versus that sort of incremental $100 million that what might have expected, you sort of brought that number down a bit last qu
componenttext: Just if you could provide a quick update on the sales teams, the new territories that have been added and how they are executing versus that sort of incremental $100 million that what might have expected, you sort of brought that number down a bit last quarter. How are those coming along and sort of where do you think full year gets us to?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the full year, we're tracking to 475 territories, which will put us up a minimum in 90 territories that we targeted for the 3-year period that's ending this December. In terms of revenue, what we're looking at right now for the full year is somewhere
componenttext: For the full year, we're tracking to 475 territories, which will put us up a minimum in 90 territories that we targeted for the 3-year period that's ending this December. In terms of revenue, what we're looking at right now for the full year is somewhere around $70 million. So we are coming up short on the $100 million target we had, but we're very pleased with the activity we have going, and we'll continue to add territories going forward.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, I guess, Mike, given that it's a little short, the $70 million, but you've had sort of really good Q1, Q2, Q3, is there something with the new sales teams that's a little slower? Are they a little slow to ramp? Is there something specific there? Or wh
componenttext: So, I guess, Mike, given that it's a little short, the $70 million, but you've had sort of really good Q1, Q2, Q3, is there something with the new sales teams that's a little slower? Are they a little slow to ramp? Is there something specific there? Or what's taking sort of them longer to ramp given the outperformance has not been driven by the newer sales teams?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bhavan, this is Steve. I would say, given what they worked through in the second half of 2008 and 2009, that sales cycle for the new accounts because these are all focused on the new accounts has really stretched about 2 years before we're in that kind of
componenttext: Bhavan, this is Steve. I would say, given what they worked through in the second half of 2008 and 2009, that sales cycle for the new accounts because these are all focused on the new accounts has really stretched about 2 years before we're in that kind of that 18-month cycle. And so that's the only difference that we've seen. What Mike referred to on the call, we are very pleased with the quality of the new accounts there in those pipelines, and the quality of the performance. It's just that the revenues dipped down. When I talked in PARTNERS last year, I thought we were about 6 months behind, that would've dipped down about 50. I said we're back up to about $75 million, $80 million and clearly end of the last quarter, we're running about $70 million. So an improvement to where I thought we were about a year ago, but the quality of the accounts is very positive. It's just really the lengthening of the sales cycle for the targeted new customers.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. If I could squeeze one more quick question, and you had a record number of new customer wins this year. Any color on how many of those are for appliances versus the EDW?
componenttext: Got it, got it. If I could squeeze one more quick question, and you had a record number of new customer wins this year. Any color on how many of those are for appliances versus the EDW?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Less than 50% are with the appliances, and then the other dimension our increase in new account wins is the new territories. So back to the new territory question, the $70 million in revenue is showing up short, but the quality of new account wins and the
componenttext: Less than 50% are with the appliances, and then the other dimension our increase in new account wins is the new territories. So back to the new territory question, the $70 million in revenue is showing up short, but the quality of new account wins and the contribution to new accounts has been extremely positive.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Katy Huberty from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Katy Huberty from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, question for you. If somebody was looking at the balance sheet in a vacuum, seeing the DSOs and inventories increase and then the lack of deferred revenue growth year on year, they might assume that you're actually trying to send the message with t
componenttext: Steve, question for you. If somebody was looking at the balance sheet in a vacuum, seeing the DSOs and inventories increase and then the lack of deferred revenue growth year on year, they might assume that you're actually trying to send the message with the guidance about decelerating growth, which I don't think is the case. So can you just comment on those 2 items? Did you see anything as it relates to timing or linearity in the third quarter that suggests we won't see a budget flush in the fourth quarter? And then on the deferred revenue line or to the fourth quarter of last year where the lower deferred revenue is actually a positive because you kept more deals in the pipeline.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me address those for you, Katy. On the DSO side, it's really the timing of the year transactions as they come through in the quarter. So if they're coming through later and they will line up, hit the receivable downside, I won't have the collecti
componenttext: Yes, let me address those for you, Katy. On the DSO side, it's really the timing of the year transactions as they come through in the quarter. So if they're coming through later and they will line up, hit the receivable downside, I won't have the collections during the quarter, if they're earlier in the quarter. So as I said in the call, on the prepared remarks, I'm comfortable on a DSO range of 75 to 85, and we're right at 80. We're 70 last year.  So there's nothing that I saw unusual in the DSO with respect to any leading indicator. So nothing in there that would change my opinion on the quality of the activity going forward. On the inventory side, it's just normal fluctuation and when we do our pre- builds versus when we're completing the shipments. There is nothing unusual in that activity. I saw a buildup in the Americas on the finished goods inventory side, which when I worked through the deals is perfectly anticipated. So the inventory buildup, other than timing ahead proposed no -- created no concern to me. On the deferred revenue side, I'm still -- I follow this metric of over 70% of our deferred revenue balance in maintenance and subscriptions. That continues to hold true on 74% as of 9/30. And so that other percentage that fluctuates significantly between quarter is the transactional side. So that side still continues to be fluctuating more, but as long as I'm over that 70% of my total deferred revenue, I feel very comfortable on. And the decrease from Q3 to Q4 -- Q2 to Q3 last year and Q2 to Q3 this year, was reasonably in line, didn't concern me, a little bit more this year, maybe like $7 million more, that didn't bother me because my percentages are still holding with the total deferred revenue. I hope that answers those questions, Katy.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just as a follow-up, what's driving the broad-based increase in product margins because you are seeing that across regions?
componenttext: Then just as a follow-up, what's driving the broad-based increase in product margins because you are seeing that across regions?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Far and beyond, it's driven by deal mix. So we had a very favorable deal mix in the third quarter. I will say there is a slight benefit of having the appliance family in that, we're able to sell products that fit the opportunity as opposed to in previous
componenttext: Far and beyond, it's driven by deal mix. So we had a very favorable deal mix in the third quarter. I will say there is a slight benefit of having the appliance family in that, we're able to sell products that fit the opportunity as opposed to in previous years, we'd be selling the EDW or the 5,000 class into a lot of these opportunities. So there's a very -- it's a very minor benefit, but it's a benefit. But the one thing I'd like to add is, previously we've been saying the appliance product margins are similar to the EDW, and even though, keep in mind, long-term we see appliances 5% to 10% of our overall product revenue mix. But we're starting to see slightly lower margins on the appliances versus the EDW, okay? If you take a look at our appliances, the have overall they have less software content than EDW, which makes them a little bit less positive in product margin, gross margin, and the 1000 class, that's that the big data, extreme data appliance, that has huge storage content. So you look at the mix of that product, the configuration, there's a lot more storage, and storage is a little lower margin. And then of course the 4000 class machine which uses the solid-state drives, that comes with a lower margin. And we're doing very well with the 1000 class series, lots of big implementations. We had one customer at our PARTNERS Conference last week that was talking about a 10 petabyte implementation, and it's a very effective solution for this big data analytic that's going on in the marketplace.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Alex Kurtz from Merriman & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Alex Kurtz from Merriman & Company.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you gave a little bit of commentary about the expected growth rates on the second half by region. I was wondering if you could give us an update across the 3 regions, sort of how you're thinking about that playing out in Q4?
componenttext: Last quarter, you gave a little bit of commentary about the expected growth rates on the second half by region. I was wondering if you could give us an update across the 3 regions, sort of how you're thinking about that playing out in Q4?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. What we were saying about the second half and as it goes into the fourth quarter is our services revenue is still growing mid-single digits. So that's kind of an overall weighting factor when we look at the second half of the year and as we go into
componenttext: Sure. What we were saying about the second half and as it goes into the fourth quarter is our services revenue is still growing mid-single digits. So that's kind of an overall weighting factor when we look at the second half of the year and as we go into the fourth quarter. Where we stand today, and I have to qualify this, that when you look at this on a region basis, you can get some pretty good swings going in one direction or another in a given quarter. And it's -- but where we stand today, APJ will be somewhat flat in the fourth quarter. Now that said, APJ is having a very, very strong year outside of Japan. We're just -- we've been experiencing softness in Japan, as well as other companies, and in Japan, doing business there. And Japan's our largest country in APJ. So in the fourth quarter and as we've seen for the year, we'll see very strong growth in APJ outside of Japan. So APJ will be flattish as we stand today. EMEA will be up double digits, we believe at this juncture. And the Americas, which really has been driving the growth all year long with incredible product revenue growth, we're looking at Americas to be mid-single digits. A minor thing about the Americas in the fourth quarter, but it is a factor, last year they grew 5% in the fourth quarter whereas previous quarters in 2009 they were going against declines. Not big declines, but declines. And this year, strength that the Americas had in product revenue in the first quarter, second quarter, third quarter, it's just not going to continue in the fourth quarter at the rate it has. It's not a red flag, it's just timing. When you step back and look at the Americas, what a fantastic year. When you step back and look at our product revenue growth and what we're doing for the year, it's a tremendous year. But we see the Americas, as we stand today, in the mid-single digits range. So that's kind of the makeup of as you look at the implied revenue growth in the fourth quarter. It's a mix of APJ flattish, EMEA kicking in; they've got good activity all year and it's kicking in the fourth quarter, they'll be up double digits; and the Americas is in the mid-single digits range as we stand today.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, those are all year-over-year Q4 to Q4 comments, right?
componenttext: Mike, those are all year-over-year Q4 to Q4 comments, right?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm sorry. Yes.
componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry. Yes.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Steve, could you talk a little bit about your thoughts of the R&D growth rates heading into next year? I know there was some accounting headwinds this year, but just what does the overall trend may look like versus the growth rate of top line?
componenttext: And Steve, could you talk a little bit about your thoughts of the R&D growth rates heading into next year? I know there was some accounting headwinds this year, but just what does the overall trend may look like versus the growth rate of top line?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Alex, I think what you're going to find this year with the acquisitions that we talked about coming on full stream in the mid-part of this year and with the FAS 86 impact that I described in my prepared remarks of $5 million in Q3 and $11 million fo
componenttext: Well, Alex, I think what you're going to find this year with the acquisitions that we talked about coming on full stream in the mid-part of this year and with the FAS 86 impact that I described in my prepared remarks of $5 million in Q3 and $11 million for full year 2010 over 2009, 2010 was a little bit abnormal, out of the ordinary with respect to that increase year-over-year. So I expect 2011 to be more in line with the spend rates of 2010, but it's really going to come down to the timing of the technological feasibility on our next major release. You know we announced 13.1 at the PARTNERS Conference, and typically we'll have a point release right after a major release and then you will have another major release coming. So it really boils down to if the next one is going to be a major release and it comes down to when we can qualify for technological feasibility that will drive that capitalization and the corresponding increase on the balance sheet and the amortization coming through as product cost. So if the timing of that holds true, then what we're anticipating I would think R&D for 2011 will be more in line with 2010.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: What is your year-over-year growth rate?
componenttext: What is your year-over-year growth rate?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The growth rate we saw in 2010 is abnormal, okay? So I'll be talking more on absolute dollars.
componenttext: The growth rate we saw in 2010 is abnormal, okay? So I'll be talking more on absolute dollars.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just one last question, just help us understand the services and support margin. What's more of a normalized rate? Obviously, it came down from Q2 to Q3, just help us think about that going into our Q4 and to next year?
componenttext: Okay, great. And just one last question, just help us understand the services and support margin. What's more of a normalized rate? Obviously, it came down from Q2 to Q3, just help us think about that going into our Q4 and to next year?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, 2009, as we said performed extremely well. The 2010 levels are probably more in line with what we would've expected. We'll continue to make those investments as we talked about in the consulting services area, and as you saw the services margin
componenttext: Yes, well, 2009, as we said performed extremely well. The 2010 levels are probably more in line with what we would've expected. We'll continue to make those investments as we talked about in the consulting services area, and as you saw the services margin overall was roughly 44% to 47% during the year, and last year services margin kicked up around to 48%. So I would say more in line, look at us in the pre-2009 levels, and it should be very similar to what you would be seeing in 2011, probably more in that 45%, 46% range.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Nabil Elsheshai from Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Nabil Elsheshai from Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the consulting side. You guys have talked about hiring this year to meet increasing demand but hasn't yet resulted in acceleration in growth on the consulting services dramatically. So when would you expect those investments to start t
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the consulting side. You guys have talked about hiring this year to meet increasing demand but hasn't yet resulted in acceleration in growth on the consulting services dramatically. So when would you expect those investments to start to drive real consulting revenue growth?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nabil, there's probably historically on average about 6- to 9-month lag on when they start becoming chargeable. And I would say probably a little bit longer when they would become fully chargeable. So I would expect that to occur, probably somewhat in the
componenttext: Nabil, there's probably historically on average about 6- to 9-month lag on when they start becoming chargeable. And I would say probably a little bit longer when they would become fully chargeable. So I would expect that to occur, probably somewhat in the second half of 2011, with respect to the investments being made in 2010. So I would still say there would be good reasonable pressure on the services revenue in total and the consulting services side through 2011. And it probably is in that mid-single -- higher single digits 7% to 8% range for 2011, if history holds true with respect to when they come online being fully chargeable, as I said, probably the second half of 2011, I was going to keep that percentage down.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then you mentioned earlier, I think Mike mentioned that you guys would continue to add sales teams. I am imagining you are going through budgeting for next year right now, but have you kind of made any decisions on the rate? Do you think you will cont
componenttext: And then you mentioned earlier, I think Mike mentioned that you guys would continue to add sales teams. I am imagining you are going through budgeting for next year right now, but have you kind of made any decisions on the rate? Do you think you will continue to add at the same rate here in the last 2 years? Or you cannot reduce the rate of new sales territory adds? Do you know that at this point?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll be increasing territories. We'll settle on and discuss more specifics on the next quarter call. Not to interpret that one way or another in terms of less than or more than or whatever. But we're seeing the kind of results that we want to see on the
componenttext: We'll be increasing territories. We'll settle on and discuss more specifics on the next quarter call. Not to interpret that one way or another in terms of less than or more than or whatever. But we're seeing the kind of results that we want to see on the new territories. We are late on the $100 million target, but we're not late on the activity, so in terms of the quality and what we're getting, we like it.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I was wondering if you could just kind of comment on the competitive environment. Some of your competitors made some pretty aggressive claims about win rates versus you guys. So particularly versus Exadata, I was wondering if you, since tha
componenttext: Okay. And then I was wondering if you could just kind of comment on the competitive environment. Some of your competitors made some pretty aggressive claims about win rates versus you guys. So particularly versus Exadata, I was wondering if you, since that's been out for a little while now, how that has impacted the competitive dynamic either in terms of pricing or in terms of your win rates?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Darryl McDonald. Yes, as it relates to competition, the playing field has been about the same as it was in the past few quarters. We still run into Oracle and again primarily with Oracle having a very large market share in the OLTP space, that's w
componenttext: This is Darryl McDonald. Yes, as it relates to competition, the playing field has been about the same as it was in the past few quarters. We still run into Oracle and again primarily with Oracle having a very large market share in the OLTP space, that's who we do see the most, and as we consolidate data marts in enterprises, either in existing customers or new customers, it is primarily Oracle. So we are continuing to take market share from that perspective. As it relates to Exadata, we haven't seen the competition increase regarding Exadata at all. So we do run into them, we do compete with them, we compete very effectively with our 2000 appliance against Exadata, and we are able to complete and effectively win there. It appears, if you look at a lot of the media and press activity, it appears that, I think a lot of the attention that Oracle is spending recently with the Exadata is more on the OLTP space against some of the OLT competitors like IBM and others.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nabil, if I can add, we need to look at our new customer wins, the vast majority of the time we're replacing somebody. When you look at our EDWs expanding and adding new applications, we're replacing data warehouses and data marts inside our account. The
componenttext: Nabil, if I can add, we need to look at our new customer wins, the vast majority of the time we're replacing somebody. When you look at our EDWs expanding and adding new applications, we're replacing data warehouses and data marts inside our account. The number of wins we have against competitors is huge. It's a very, very large number. Our growth doesn't come from just our data warehouse installed and the customer just grows itself and stays within a subject area, and organically there's more revenue. Our growth comes from replacing stuff, and it's across the board, new customers and our existing customers and everything else. Our product revenue growth this year, you take a look at the levels of our product revenue growth, we're replacing more stuff than we've ever replaced in the past 10 years.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last question on the SAS partnership side. So at the conference, it looked like that we're targeting a November data for the SAP partnership. When you look at that timing and then when it would go GA, is your expectation that any imp
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last question on the SAS partnership side. So at the conference, it looked like that we're targeting a November data for the SAP partnership. When you look at that timing and then when it would go GA, is your expectation that any impacts financially could be delayed until 2012 or maybe late 2011? And then on the SAS partnership that's been out for a while, the feedback was pretty positive but I was wondering is there any way to talk about how that impacts your revenue opportunity and maybe incremental opportunities that could generate if any?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll be glad to talk about both of those. You're correct regarding the SAP BW port to Teradata. We are following the SAP ramp-up schedule for BW 7.14, and we are targeted to go into ramp-up in the November, December timeframe. So we do have customers
componenttext: Yes, I'll be glad to talk about both of those. You're correct regarding the SAP BW port to Teradata. We are following the SAP ramp-up schedule for BW 7.14, and we are targeted to go into ramp-up in the November, December timeframe. So we do have customers that have been identified for that, and then that would put us into their cycle that would have us in Q1 doing the betas and then going GCA at the end of Q2. So to your point, we wouldn't look to be then taking it to market in a broad way until the second half of 2011. And we do work together following SAP schedule on that and their certification process and ramp-up process. So we're trying to move with that schedule and with the market to stay aligned there. We still do have lots of interest and lots of opportunity from customers wanting to integrate both their BW analytics and their non-SAP analytics into a common platform, and we think Teradata will be the best at that. As it relates to SAS, we are seeing good momentum with SAS. We continue to build on our strategy there. We have a 3-pronged approach around the things we were reporting and going to market weighted and we are seeing good traction in our industry app. So we've got good examples of where incrementally we are able to pull SAS analytics onto Teradata and/or SAS applications onto Teradata, and we have several of our great customers showcased at PARTNERS talking about that. So we hope to get a chance to see some of those, but we've had any money laundering applications from SAS, that we've been ought to put on Teradata and of course what that does is, it allows us to leverage the EDW that's in place, the data that's in place, and add new business value to their enterprise. So we are continuing to port and release industry applications, the latest of course, was the manufacturing warranty and analytics that we think will have good upside in helping customers determine their early warranty problems. And then also we just recently ported their customer application, customer marketing application to Teradata and had good success in that in Q3.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Matt Summerville from KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question comes from Matt Summerville from KeyBanc.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, as we think about and I know you don't want to get specific necessarily, Mike, about your sales plans for the next year or 2. As we think about that dynamic, as we think about some of the other spending dynamics, R&D, et cetera that
componenttext: Two questions. First, as we think about and I know you don't want to get specific necessarily, Mike, about your sales plans for the next year or 2. As we think about that dynamic, as we think about some of the other spending dynamics, R&D, et cetera that you've highlighted today. Steve, one of the comments you made is that right now you're kind of thinking about earnings growth at a 1.5x or 1.5x sales growth rate. When do you think you start to get back to that to kind of range? Does that happen in 2011 or should we think about that more for 2012 at this point?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt. What I've been saying is that 2012 is our first year over year full year comparison, if we don't do anything accelerated with respect to our increase, with respect to sales territories, our R&D out of the normal. So if we continue on the path o
componenttext: Yes, Matt. What I've been saying is that 2012 is our first year over year full year comparison, if we don't do anything accelerated with respect to our increase, with respect to sales territories, our R&D out of the normal. So if we continue on the path of investing strategically in sales territories and that, that could push it out longer, but if we go back down to a more normalized historical, then that would be 2012 will be the first one. So it really comes down to net core investments on the strategic sales territory expansion R&D.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The one thing that I want to make sure, I have a clear understanding, you talked about, and I think people are focusing on this $100 million you expected to get out of the class of folks and territories you've brought in over the last couple of years. You
componenttext: The one thing that I want to make sure, I have a clear understanding, you talked about, and I think people are focusing on this $100 million you expected to get out of the class of folks and territories you've brought in over the last couple of years. You talked about kind of $70 million number, but that being a higher quality $70 million number. I guess maybe one way to think about it is if you look out 5 years, how much difference or what do you think the net worth is of the $70 million in revenue that you're getting versus what you originally targeted? I guess I'm trying to understand how you're looking at the quality aspect of that revenue. I would assume the future value is more substantial?

And that's why we want to continue to add sales territories. We want to -- we do want to get a good yield on the revenue short-term, and we comments about 2011 here. But at the same time, we want to build the pipelines for revenue growth for the years beyond as well. So it's a balance.

componenttext: Welcome to Teradata's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's conference. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Gregg Swearingen, Vice President, Investor Relations. Mr. Swearingen, you may begin.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for our 2010 third quarter earnings call. Mike Koehler, Teradata's CEO, will begin our discussion summarizing Teradata's third quarter results. Steve Scheppmann, Teradata's Chief Financial Officer, will then provide
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for our 2010 third quarter earnings call. Mike Koehler, Teradata's CEO, will begin our discussion summarizing Teradata's third quarter results. Steve Scheppmann, Teradata's Chief Financial Officer, will then provide more details relating to our financial performance as well as our increased 2010 guidance. Darryl McDonald, Teradata's Executive Vice President of Business Development and Marketing is also in the room to answer questions.
Our discussion today includes forecast and other information that are considered forward-looking statements. While these statements reflect our current outlook, they are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to vary materially. These risk factors are described in Teradata's 10-K and other filings with the SEC. On today's call, we will also be discussing certain non-GAAP financial information such as earnings per share, excluding stock-based compensation expense, free cash flow and revenue comparisons in constant currency. A reconciliation of our non-GAAP results to our reported GAAP results and other information concerning these measures of is included in our earnings release and on the Investor page of Teradata's website, teradata.com. A replay of this conference call will also be available later today on our website. Teradata assumes no obligation to update or revise the information included in this conference call whether as a result of new information or future results. I'll now turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gregg. And good morning, everyone. Teradata has delivered another strong quarter in Q3, with revenue growth of 15% and operating income growth of 20% versus prior year. Product revenue was up 27% in the quarter and for the year is up 25%. This is
componenttext:
Thanks, Gregg. And good morning, everyone. Teradata has delivered another strong quarter in Q3, with revenue growth of 15% and operating income growth of 20% versus prior year. Product revenue was up 27% in the quarter and for the year is up 25%. This is the highest total revenue growth and product revenue growth we have achieved during the past 10 years.
Data volumes continue to grow exponentially, with new data types coming from new data sources. As companies look to bring these new data elements together with traditional data, this makes for an attractive market opportunity for Teradata and our integrated active data warehouses. This has also created demand for our appliances to address big data and other evolving opportunities in large, single subject data marts. We continue to innovate on many fronts to capitalize on the evolving landscape from big data to advanced analytics, to enterprise marketing management, to mobile intelligence. These innovations are translating into growth in our customer base and growth in the number of customers that Teradata serves. New customer wins year-to-date are at our highest levels in 6 years.
Turning to the regions, the Americas had strong growth again in Q3, with revenue of $292 million, which was up 18% over 2009. New account wins included a world leading manufacturer of aircraft engines, which will integrate and analyze large volumes of text analytics. This will enable them to quickly detect and react to changes that impact its forecasting and manufacturing schedules, which will in turn reduce inventory and service cost. 
Other new account wins included a major high-tech manufacturer and Procter & Gamble and a leading department store retailer as well as the top 2 banks in Mexico and one in Chile. Customer upgrades and expansions included WellPoint, which has added our solid-state drive appliance to deliver critical care alerts to hospital staff and physicians within seconds.
Our Extreme Performance data warehouse, the 4600 Appliance is enabling new time-sensitive, mission-critical, breakthrough applications that were not possible before. Additional upgrades and expansions in the quarter included Nationwide Insurance, Caterpillar Logistics and Enterprise Holdings, which includes Alamo, National and Enterprise Rent-A-Cars and one of the world's largest retailers and one of the world's largest manufacturers of phones and computers. Overall, the Americas is having an outstanding 2010 to date in terms of total revenue growth, product revenue growth and new customer wins. 
In EMEA, Q3 revenue of $109 million was equal to prior year, but it was up 7% in constant currency. New account wins included Unilever, a leading consumer packaged goods company. We are working with CPG manufacturers around the world to integrate, explore and analyze their consumer and retail point-of-sale information to better understand preferences and build brand loyalty. 
EMEA also had 4 government new account wins with 2 in Turkey and one each in Italy and Belarus.
The government sector, as you all know, is an under-penetrated vertical for Teradata and is a big opportunity for us. Upgrades and expansions in the quarter included Lufthansa, which is adding operational over active decision-making and is also redesigning their customer loyalty program and integrating it with partner airlines. And we had expansions at Lloyds, DHL, Telenor Pakistan, the Italian Tax Authority, COOP Norden, Mobinil in Egypt and at Chronopost International in France.
For the first 3 quarters of 2010, EMEA's revenue was flat with 2009 as reported and up 2% in constant currency. However, keep in mind, EMEA was going against the good prior year comparable when revenue grew 9% in constant currency through Q3 2009. EMEA's overall activity has been solid in 2010, and we expect good growth in Q4.
Asia Pacific Japan had an excellent quarter, generating $88 million of revenue in Q3, which was a 28% increase over the third quarter of 2009. In constant currency, APJ grew 19%. China is having a strong 2010, and we continue to see good growth in financial services there, our largest industry.
In Q3, we added Ping An Bank as a new customer, and they will be consolidating 26 data marts into our centralized EDW. Ping An Bank joins a growing number of financial services institutions relying on Teradata to provide a single view of the customer, reduce credit risk and drive top and bottom line results. 
During the third quarter, we also recognize significant expansions at several of China's top 5 banks, including ICBC, China Construction Bank and the Bank of Communications.
Across APJ, active EDW implementations are fulfilling mission-critical needs as well. A good example is the Australian border control, which is processing data from a wide range of sources, including near realtime data. The agency will utilize Teradata's event-triggering techniques to rapidly identify, analyze and respond to situations to ensure the safety of Australia's borders.
APJ also saw good growth from a number of other customers across the region in Q3, including the Australian tax authority; in Japan, Rakuten, Japan's largest online retailer; JCB; Mitsui Foods; and Sony Marketing and in the Philippines, Globe Telecom.
Overall, APJ has grown revenue 15% this year as reported and 7% in constant currency. Growth has been especially strong in the countries outside of Japan. Our Annual Partners Conference was held in San Diego last week with over 3,000 attendees and 169 customers presenting at various sessions there.
One of the common themes from customers in Teradata was how to innovate with the wave of new big data. In particular, how to leverage the big data being driven from weblogs, smartphones, social media, sensors, et cetera, together with what they already know such as customers, products and supply chains.
Organizations that move quickly and figure out how to leverage this new information will have a clear competitive advantage in the marketplace, and Teradata is helping them to do that. I'd like to highlight a few of our announcements from the conference.
We introduced Teradata database 13.10, which further extends our lead with temporal and compression capabilities among other things. Teradata's temporal software automatically timestamps data to allow customers to track and properly account through changes that evolve in their business over time. For example, manufacturers can obtain more meaningful sales performance reports that account for territory realignments or customer mergers and acquisitions that have occurred over the years. And retailers can get sales comparisons that reflect products changing the different categories.
The Teradata database 13.10 has enhanced compression technologies that enable customers to store more data. Customers are receiving up to 20x compression for select data types and up to 4x for overall compression.
We also released the next generation of our platform family of partners, which significantly boost performance across all models and reduces energy consumption as well. For example, our 5650 Active Enterprise Data Warehouse delivers a 43% performance boost over the previous generation and does this in the same-sized footprint, which reduces energy and floor space requirements.
In addition, we announced enhancements to our Customer Relationship Management application which we call TRM. New features include mobile intelligence capabilities, customized reporting and visualization tools. Now marketers and executives can visualize their data and access reports and dashboards across all medium channels from a variety of platforms, including mobile devices and iPads.
In summary, we see more opportunities than ever before to help customers drive value through data warehousing. And we remain confident in our ability to execute with customers and in the market with our best-in-class technology, solutions and the world's best data warehousing consulting practice.
Given our performance in Q3, we are increasing our guidance for 2010 revenue growth to be approximately 12%, and we're increasing our non-GAAP EPS guidance to the $1.80 to $1.83 range.
Now I'll turn the call over to Steve for more details. Steve?

headline: Teradata Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. This quarter, we improved our revenue growth rates, expanded our gross and operating margins and increased our EPS.Now moving to our revenue details. Revenue of $489 million was up 15% from the thir
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. This quarter, we improved our revenue growth rates, expanded our gross and operating margins and increased our EPS.
Now moving to our revenue details. Revenue of $489 million was up 15% from the third quarter of 2009 and also up 15% in constant currency. Revenue for the first 9 months of the year was up 14%, 13% in constant currency. Product revenue of $243 million was up 27% from the third quarter of 2009 and up 25% for the first 9 months.
Services revenue of $246 million was up 5% and 6% year-to-date. Within services, during Q3, consulting services revenue was up 6% and maintenance services revenue was up 5%.
Turning to our gross margind. Gross margin in the third quarter improved to 57.1% compared to 53.4% in the third quarter of 2009. Higher product gross margin and a more favorable mix of product revenue versus services revenue more than offset a lower services gross margin in the quarter. Prior gross margin of 70.4% increased from 62.3% in Q3, 2009. The increase was primarily driven by a positive deal mix, particularly in the Americas region.
Services gross margin in Q3 of 43.9% was lower than the strong services gross margin of 46.2% achieved in Q3 2009. Our consulting services business is expanding their headcount in response to growing business opportunities. As we've discussed in prior quarters, this new headcount can have a negative impact on margin, particularly while the new consultants are being trained and are not yet fully productive or chargeable.
Our data warehousing consulting capability is unmatched and a very important part of our business model. Not only does it enable us to grow services revenue, but it may open the door to future product revenue opportunities.
Moving to a geographical view of gross margin. In the Americas region, gross margin was 61.6%, an improvement from 55.9% in the third quarter of 2009, driven primarily by higher product margins as well as a higher proportion of product revenue as compared to services revenue.
Gross margin in the EMEA region of 51.4% was down from the 53.2% reported in the third quarter of 2009, driven by lower services margins, which were offset somewhat by the improved product margins. 
Gross margin in the APJ region was 48.9%, up from the 44.9% in Q3 2009. The increase was primarily driven by higher product margin as well as a greater proportion of product revenue as compared to the services revenue.
Turning to our expense structure. SG&A expense in Q3 2010 increased $20 million from a year ago. The increase was largely driven by increased selling expenses associated with our strategic initiatives of expanding our sales territories as well as higher variable incentive compensation across the company.
As we discussed last quarter, we expected this level of increase in SG&A expenses as the third quarter of 2009 was abnormally low due to timing, and we curtailed the expenses due to the economy downturn and the associated uncertainty.
R&D in the quarter was $40 million versus $26 million in the third quarter of 2009. As anticipated, we continue to invest in our market-leading technology. For the full year 2010, we expect R&D to be approximately $150 million. FAS 86 unfavorably impacted R&D expense $5 million in Q3 as compared to Q3 2009 and will have an anticipated nonfavorable impact of approximately $11 million for 2010 as compared to 2009.
As a result of all these items discussed, Teradata's operating margin in the third quarter increased to 21.7% versus 20.7% reported in Q3 2009. Increased investments in sales territories and R&D will create more of a headwind on operating margin and EPS in Q4.
That said, however, for the full year 2010, we now expect operating margin to be approximately 21%, higher than the 19% to 20% original guidance range we provided earlier this year below the operating income line. The effective income tax rate in the third quarter of 2010 was 29%, which compared to a 25% effective tax rate in the prior period, driven by an overall proportional increase in U.S. pre-tax earnings. For the full year, Teradata expects a higher proportion of its pre-tax income will be generated in the United States in 2010 as compared to 2009. As a result, we are anticipating the full year effective tax rate to be approximately 27%. However, if the U.S. federal R&D tax credit is not retroactively reinstated by Congress before year end, our full year effective tax rate for 2010 will increase to approximately 28%.
GAAP EPS in Q3 2010 was $0.44 versus $0.36 in Q3 2009. Noncash stock-based compensation expense is included in our EPS results. During the quarter, stock-based compensation expense was approximately $7 million or approximately $0.02 per share.
Non-GAAP EPS for the third quarter, excluding the stock-based compensation expense, was $0.46 in the third quarter of 2010. This compares to $0.40 in the third quarter of 2009, excluding stock-based compensation expense as well as an impairment charge that we took in the third quarter of 2009.
For the full year, we expect approximately the same amount of stock-based compensation expense in 2010 as we had in 2009, roughly $24 million, or approximately $0.09 per share for the full year. As a reminder, we have a table on the footnotes of our earnings release, as well as detailed schedules on our website that reconciles the differences between our GAAP and non-GAAP results and outlook.
Focusing on cash flow, cash from operating activities was $65 million in Q3 2010, versus a $96 million generated in the third quarter of 2009. When comparing to the prior year period, the decrease in cash provided by operating activities was principally driven by the anticipated increase in our receivables balance as well as the higher inventory levels, which are used as a working capital. After $18 million of capital expenditures versus $21 million of CapEx in the third quarter of 2009, we generated $47 million of free cash flow, down from the $75 million free cash flow in Q3 of 2009.
In Q3 2010, the timing of the meaningful revenue growth added to our receivables balance and increased our working capital needs as one would expect. In 2008 and 2009, free cash flow benefited from working down our receivables balance and improving our DSO. Our free cash flow is now expected to run in line with the plus or minus $25 million of net income annual guidance metric we talked about since the spin-off.
Teradata defines free cash flow as cash flow from operating activities less capital expenditures for property and equipment and additions to capitalized software.
With respect to our balance sheet. As of September 30, 2010, we have $741 million of cash, a $17 million increase from the end of the second quarter of 2010. During the third quarter, we used $29 million for tuck-in technology investments and used approximately $17 million to repurchase 559,000 shares of our stock.
As we've said before, we expect that the rate of our buyback will continue to fluctuate each quarter, taking into account, among other things, our working capital needs, our stock price, potential alternative uses of cash such as acquisitions and economic and market conditions.
At the end of Q3 2010, approximately 67% of our cash was held outside the United States and in effect not available for share repurchases unless we repatriate the cash back to the U.S. and pay the corresponding taxes at a significant tax cost.
With respect to our receivables. Our day sales outstanding was 80 days as of September 30, 2010, compared to 70 days as of September 30, 2009. Again, we target approximately 75 to 85 as our DSO targets. To provide further transparency around our currency movement, we provided on our website additional detail regarding how currencies moved in Q3 2010, and how this movement is expected to impact our year over year revenue comparisons for the remainder of 2010, assuming the currency exchange rates as of the end of October.
As I mentioned earlier, our Q3 total company year over year revenue comparison was not impacted by currency translation, but EMEA region did see 7 points of currency headwind in the year-over-year revenue comparison in the quarter, while APJ benefited from 9 percentage points of currency tailwind. Currencies moved in the favorable directions since our last earnings call. As a result, we now expect 0% to 1% of currency benefit both in the fourth quarter and for the full year revenue comparison.
As Mike said earlier in the call, we are increasing our full year 2010 and EPS guidance ranges. We increased our expectation for revenue growth from the higher end of the 8% to 10% guidance range to approximately 12% and GAAP EPS from the $1.60 to $1.70 to the $1.71 to $1.74 range. Excluding stock-based compensation expense, non-GAAP EPS is now expected to be in the $1.80 to $1.83 range.
As we discussed in the past and as we saw in Q3, some of our cost and expense lines continue to grow faster than normal due to increased investments in sales coverage and R&D along with a more normalized spending in 2010. As a result, we expect our EPS growth to be less than our long-term target of growing EPS at twice our revenue growth, probably more in the 1.5x range. Specifically, as we discussed last quarter and saw in Q3, we anticipate headwind in Q4 from the following factors.
R&D for the full year increasing to approximately $150 million, $11 million due to FAS 86 compared to the 2009 level of $117 million; annualized higher selling expense due to more sales territories and increased training costs associated with new territories and headcount; normal increases in G&A, such as base compensation increases and a return of expenses that were eliminated or reduced in 2009, including training and education; lower services gross margin, as we add to our consulting teams; and finally, potentially higher incentive compensation across the company as the company is performing better relative to key incentive plan metrics as compared to 2009.
That said, we are very pleased with our year-to-date performance, and we feel very good about our technology and competitive leadership positions, which is clearly reflected in our operating results. And consequently, we have increased our guidance for both revenue growth and EPS for 2010.
And with that, operator, we're ready to take questions.
